awd_abstract_narration:
Cluster algebras are a fundamental mathematical structure employed to describe highly symmetric mathematical objects. In the last decade, cluster structures have been constructed on spaces throughout representation theory and mathematical physics, most recently in the theory of scattering amplitudes in high-energy particle physics. This project comprises fundamental mathematical research into the combinatorial structure of several crucial cluster algebras, and the geometric spaces related to them. 

This research project addresses several questions concerning the combinatorial structure of various cluster algebras. Most of these cluster algebras come from natural spaces in algebraic geometry, such as open positroid varieties, which occur in stratifying the Grassmannian and generalized Teichmuller spaces. The first part of the project investigates the coefficients of the Laurent polynomials that occur in changing from one cluster to another in the Grassmannian (and other related spaces). The second part of the project aims to determine the relation between the parametrizations of positroid cells by dimer configurations on tori and the values of Plucker coordinates as charts on those cells. The third part of the project investigates the cohomology of cluster varieties, trying to find presentations for the cohomology ring that are as explicit and combinatorial as the presentations already known for the coordinate rings.

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this project was to produce new combinatorial models for the study of cluster algebras, and discover new cluster algebra related phenomena.

During the period of the grant, the PI completed three major papers on this theme. "Cohomology of cluster varieties. I" (with Thomas Lam), showed that the de Rham cohomology rings of cluster varieties are as combinatorially rich as their coordinate rings and set up the technology to study them. "The twist for positroid varieties" (with Greg Muller) fills in many missing points in Postnikov's parameterization of the totally nonnegative Grassmannian. This paper created the context for Lam and Galashin to prove that all positroid varieties have cluster structure; a problem which has been open since the mid-2000's. "The fundamental theorem of finite semidistributive lattices", (with Nathan Reading and Hugh Thomas) created the vocabulary for constructing infinite lattices which can play the same role in describing infinite type cluster algebras that the weak orders due in finite type. The PI also wrote a short note, "Variations on a theme of Kasteleyn, with application to the totally nonnegative Grassmannian," cleaning up many of the combinatorial lemmas used in Postnikov's parametrization of the totally nonnegative Grassmannian. The PI also wrote nine other papers in other areas of math.

The PI graduated four students during the period of the grant: Gracie Ingermanson,  Jake Levinson, Rohini Ramadas and Harry Richman. Ingermanson's dissertation answered a major question in the theory of cluster algebras, constructing a cluster structure on positroid varieties. Ingermanson want on to work in industry; the other three students are pursing careers in academia: Levinson took a postdoc at the University of Washington and now has a tenure track position at Simon Fraser University; Ramadas took postdocs at Harvard and Brown; Richman took a postdoc at the University of Washington. The PI also started working with two new graduate students, Shelby Cox and Will Dana. Dana is working on questions related to quiver representations and root systems which are connected to the PI's work on models of cluster algebras coming from Coxeter theory; it is not yet clear what Cox will work on.

In the period of the grant, the PI mentored two undergraduate researchers: Shubhankar Sahai and Grant Barkley. Barkley's work on Coxeter root systems provides valuable test cases for the PI's hope to relate his work on modeling cluster algebras using Coxeter groups to Dyer's conjectures on root systems.
